code-table.description: Basic Genre Terms for Cultural Heritage Materials

item.label: advertisements
item.description: An item printed solely as a means of advertising a product or service, but not an event.

item.label: albums
item.description: Bound or loose-leaf sets of pages. Includes handmade albums and published volumes of blank pages designed for the addition of images or keepsakes.

item.label: architecture
item.description: Includes drawings and photos.

item.label: baseball Cards
item.description: Advertising or collectible cards that feature portraits of baseball players, other people, or topics associated with the game. Introduced in 1886 or 1887 by a tobacco company; also popular with bubble gum manufacturers beginning in the 1930s. Common sizes include 1.5 x 2.5 inches, 2.5 x 3.5 inches, and ca. 5 x 8 inches. The cards may be actual photographs mounted on card stock or photomechanically printed.

item.label: blank forms
item.description: Forms that have been printed blank, which may or may not have been filled in; the document was typically meant to be returned to the publisher (e.g., subscription lists, petitions).

item.label: books
item.description: Published non-periodical volumes in bound codex form, usually with 49 or more pages.

item.label: broadsides
item.description: Single-sheet notices or announcements pinted on one or both sides, intended to be read unfolded.

item.label: cartoons (Commentary)
item.description: Pictorial images using wit to comment on such things as contemporary events, social habits, or political trends; usually executed in a broad or abbreviated manner.

item.label: catalogs
item.description: Enumerations of items arranged systematically with descriptive details. May have prices.

item.label: cityscapes
item.description: General or broad views of cities and towns or sections of them. Usually made from an elevated or distant vantage point, such as a view from a roof or a view of a skyline.

item.label: clippings
item.description: Objects with physical evidence suggesting extraction from a larger entity (e.g., books, newspapers).

item.label: correspondence
item.description: Communication by the exchange of letters.

item.label: diaries
item.description: A daily record, especially a personal record of events, experiences, and observations; a journal.

item.label: drawings
item.description: Narrower terms include both physical media and genre categories but are limited to those which use drawing in the sense of a specific medium rather than in the everyday sense of graphic representation.

item.label: ephemera
item.description: Transient everyday items, usually printed and on paper, that are manufactured for a specific limited use, then often discarded. Includes everyday items that are meant to be saved, at least for a while, such as KEEPSAKES and STOCK CERTIFICATES.

item.label: essays
item.description: A short literary composition on a single subject, usually presenting the personal view of the author.

item.label: ethnography
item.description: Documentation made for or by anthropologists and others involved in the systematic recording of human cultures.

item.label: fieldnotes
item.description: Notes, often in books, kept by researchers or surveying parties while on site.

item.label: illustrations
item.description: Images that explain or elaborate a written or spoken text; may be issued separately from the text.

item.label: interviews
item.description: A conversation, such as one conducted by a reporter, in which facts or statements are elicited from another.

item.label: landscapes
item.description: General or broad views of natural scenery, including inland bodies of water; may also include figures or man-made objects, but these are of secondary importance to the composition. Usually made from an elevated or distant vantage point, such as a view from a hill; not ground level close-up view of, for example, a tree.

item.label: leaflets
item.description: Unbound volumes with fewer than five pages.

item.label: manuscripts
item.description: A book, document, or other composition written by hand. A typewritten or handwritten version of a book, an article, a document, or other work, especially the author's own copy, prepared and submitted for publication in print. Handwriting.

item.label: maps
item.description: Graphic delineations at a set scale, of all or part of the earth or another celestial sphere indicating the relative position of selected artificial and natural features.

item.label: miscellaneous Documents
item.description: A written or printed paper that bears the original, official, or legal form of something and can be used to furnish decisive evidence or information.

item.label: motion Pictures
item.description: Used for Cinema, Films, Movies, Moving pictures.

item.label: music
item.description: The art of arranging sounds in time so as to produce a continuous, unified, and evocative composition, as through melody, harmony, rhythm, and timbre.

item.label: narratives
item.description: A narrated account; a story.

item.label: paintings
item.description: Color paint applied by hand to a surface (support) such as paper, canvas, wood, glass, or other.

item.label: pamphlets
item.description: Published non-periodical volumes with no cover or with a paper cover. Usually 5 or more pages and fewer than 49 pages.

item.label: periodicals
item.description: Serials usually issued at regular intervals and more frequently than annually.

item.label: petitions
item.description: Includes activities involved in petitioning.

item.label: photographs
item.description: A general designation for any photographic process. The narrower terms include both physical media and genre categories.

item.label: physical Objects
item.description: Something perceptible by one or more of the senses, especially by vision or touch; a material thing.

item.label: poetry
item.description: A piece of literature written in meter; verse.

item.label: portraits
item.description: Graphic representations, especially of the face, of real persons, usually posed, living or dead. Pictures whose purpose is the portrayal of an individual or several people, not pictures that merely include people as part of an event or scene.

item.label: postcards
item.description: Cards on which a message may be written or printed for mailing without an envelope; often include a pictorial, comic, or other scene on one side.

item.label: posters
item.description: Single or multi-sheet notices made to attract attention to events, activities, cuases, goods, or services; also, purely decorative posters. For posting, usually in a public place; chiefly pictorial. Intended to make an immediate impression from a distance.

item.label: prints
item.description: Images formed by transfer from one surface or source to another. Usually created with ink(s) and produced in multiple impressions.

item.label: programs
item.description: Lists of the events, pieces, performers, speakers, etc., of an entertainment, ceremony, or the like.

item.label: recording logs
item.description: Sequential lists or summaries of the contents or events on sound or video recordings.

item.label: scores
item.description: The written form of a composition for orchestral or vocal parts.

item.label: sheet Music
item.description: Unbound songs and other pieces of music on eight or fewer pages.

item.label: timetables
item.description: Items printed solely for use as timetables (e.g., train schedules).

item.label: transcriptions
item.description: Something that has been transcribed, especially: Music. An adaptation of a composition. A recorded radio or television program. Linguistics. A representation of speech sounds in phonetic symbols.
